claim:
Consider the following background information: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of burning sensation in his mouth. One year ago, a peripheral blood smear performed during workup of fatigue revealed erythrocytes without central pallor. His father had gallstones, for which he underwent a cholecystectomy at the age of 26 years. Examination shows pallor of the mucosal membranes, mild scleral icterus, a swollen, red tongue, and several mouth ulcers. There is darkening of the skin over the dorsal surfaces of the fingers, toes, and creases of the palms and soles. His spleen is enlarged and palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.1 gm/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 104 μm3, and a reticulocyte count of 9%.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: A gluten-free diet would most likely have prevented this patient"s oropharyngeal symptoms.

supporting.text: The patient's symptoms, including oral burning, swollen red tongue, and mouth ulcers, are classic manifestations of celiac disease, which is treated with a gluten-free diet.

attacks.text: The patient's symptoms, including oral burning, swollen red tongue, and mouth ulcers, are classic manifestations of celiac disease, which is treated with a gluten-free diet.

The patient's laboratory findings (hemoglobin 9.1 g/dL, MCV 104, reticulocyte count 9%) and physical exam findings (splenomegaly, skin hyperpigmentation) are more consistent with hemolytic anemia, not celiac disease.
The absence of central pallor on peripheral smear and family history of gallstones suggest hereditary spherocytosis, which explains all findings without invoking celiac disease.
While oral manifestations can occur in celiac disease, the patient's scleral icterus and splenomegaly are not typical features of this condition.
The patient's macrocytic anemia could alternatively be explained by vitamin B12 deficiency, which also causes glossitis and oral ulcers, independent of gluten sensitivity.
